author: brent.allsop
content:
Permissioned wiki, people can’t edit, lol.  Good example of an oxymoron.
Wikipedia is already polarizing enough with edit wars, adding permissions and forks just makes polarization worse.
Instead of censoring, we should push a wiki towards consensus by adding camps.

author: brent.allsop
content: So everyone is at least in the same place.

author: sky.cactus
content: I have argued against eth.wiki not just linking over to GitHub where anyone can PR.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is a GitTub repository that backs eth.wiki, I just forget where it is and the site doesn't link to it when you try to edit.

author: brent.allsop
content:
A GitHub repository that backs a wiki.  Things just get better and better.
I’m assuming you are talking about this:
https://github.com/ethereum/eth-wiki
<@!301186049323958275>, are you saying you have already edited this (done a pull request?), but it didn’t get pushed to the wiki?

author: sky.cactus
content: I have made edits.  Took a while to get approved, but it went through.

author: sky.cactus
content: That looks like the right repo.

author: sky.cactus
content: And the change is now live.

author: brent.allsop
content: Whew.  Lot of messy, slow, non  single source of truth steps.  But at least it finally works.

author: brent.allsop
content: <@!489256758989029405>, does that answer your question about how to get your link  added?  Just do a pull request here: https://github.com/ethereum/eth-wiki

author: brent.allsop
content: And by the way, I am with Micah on what should be considered “official”.  Just because Geth and Trinity are both under the same hierarchy, or they are deemed official by some permissioned page, does not make them ‘official’ in my view.  In a non-permissioned, bottom up win/win systems, what is ‘official’ is determined by popularity, as in the next rising start rapidly growing in popularity (if you have the ability to track and measure that.)
